Description: Terracotta ithyphallic figure plaque, possibly of Harpocrates. A seated man holding, with both hands (as if playing a harp), his huge phallus, which rises up and curves over, the glans resting on top of his head. He is naked; it is uncertain whether he has hair or is shaven: there is an apparent hairline, or a hat, possibly kausia (?). His legs are largely lost. The back is flat. Solid; one-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a thick grey core; traces of a white dressing remain, painted pink in the flesh areas.
Curator's comments: A parallel from a late fifth century BC context was found at Leontopolis in the Delta. (Redmount & Friedman 1997, 65, fig. 7). Registered with other objects known to come from Naukratis, but acquired for the Museum secretum in 1868. Redmount, C. A. & Friedman, R. F. 1997. Tales of a Delta Site: Preliminary Report on the 1995 Field Season at Tell el-Muqdam. ‘Journal of the American Research Center in Egypt’ 34; 57-83.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3228)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.098) (Phase 1)
